summary: The West African Court of Appeal dismissed an application for leave to appeal brought by James Latunde Aderokun against the United Africa Co. Ltd on 17th April 1936. The Court held that it had discretion under Rule 11 of its rules to refuse the application and determined that no special grounds justified granting leave. It emphasized that the appellant was already pursuing remedies in another court with undisputed jurisdiction and could obtain full redress there. Allowing the appeal would encourage multiplicity of proceedings, which the Court sought to avoid. The application was dismissed with costs assessed at five guineas.
legalKeywords: West African Court of Appeal Rules
rationaleHighlights: Court has discretion under Rule 11 to grant or refuse leave to appeal
No special grounds shown for appeal
Appellant already pursuing remedy in another competent court
Full redress available in alternative forum
confidenceNotes: High confidence; details are drawn directly from the original decision text with clear attribution of court, parties, judges, and reasoning.
